Question: Why do most individuals (adults and children) develop cancer?
CorrectAnswer: Cancer is most often due to a series of random somatic mutations over a person's lifetime
Answer1: Cancer is most often due to inherited genetic risk
Answer2: Cancer is most often the direct result of environmental mutagens
Answer3: Cancer is most often due to personal risk factors like poor diet and obesity

Question: Which of the following statements regarding breast cancer is FALSE?
CorrectAnswer: An Ashkenazi Jewish woman newly diagnosed with breast cancer has the same risk to be a BRCA 1/2 mutation carrier as a newly diagnosed non-Ashkenazi Jewish woman (if both same age and negative family history)
Answer1: Up to 70 % of breast cancer is sporadic and not felt to be hereditary or part of a family cluster
Answer2: A male with breast cancer at any age is a candidate for genetic counseling
Answer3: BRCA1 mutation related breast cancers tend to have pathological features that are distinctive from BRCA2 or sporadic breast tumors

Question: Which of the following statement(s) are true about variants of uncertain significance found when testing for mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2?
CorrectAnswer: Variants of unknown signficance are more commonly found in those of African ancestry
Answer1: If a variant of uncertain significance is observed along with a deleterious mutation in the same gene in the same individual, there is still no further evidence about whether or not the variant has significance
Answer2: Variants of unknown significance are most commonly nonsense alterations
Answer3: BRCA1/2 variants of uncertain significance are present in fewer than 1 % of individuals of European ancestry

Question: Which of the following breast cancer biopsy findings is/are associated with a moderate or high risk for developing breast cancer?
CorrectAnswer: Atypical hyperplasia
Answer2: Duct ectasia

Question: An individual with Lynch syndrome who has a characteristic presentation of this condition would most likely have:
CorrectAnswer: About 15 adenomatous colon polyps
Answer1: About 100 hamartomatous colon polyps or more
Answer2: About 100 adenomatous colon polyps or more

Question: When immunohistochemical (IHC) staining is performed on a colon tumor looking for clues about Lynch syndrome, loss of staining for which gene is most likely to be representative of somatic mutation?
CorrectAnswer: MLH1
Answer2: MSH3

Question: What is the common mechanism by which a Lynch syndrome gene may be somatically altered so that it is no longer functional, and therefore produces no protein and absence of staining on IHC analysis?
CorrectAnswer: Promotor methylation
Answer2: Missense mutation

Question: Which statements about the Amsterdam criteria for Lynch syndrome or HNPCC is correct?
CorrectAnswer:
An individual with colon cancer from a family meeting Amsterdam criteria has his turnor studies, and it does not demonstrate MSI or loss of staining. He most likely has hereditary colon cancer 
syndrome
Answer1:
Over 90% of families who meet the strict Amsterdam criteria will 
have a detectable mutation found in one of the HNPCC genes
Answer2: An individual with colon cancer from a family meeting the Amsterdam criteria has his tumor studied, and it does not demonstrate MSI or loss of staining. He most likely still haş Lynch syndrome
Answer3: To fulfill the Amsterdam criteria, at least one relative must be diagnosed with colon cancer prior to the age of 40

Question: PMS2 is a Lynch syndrome gene with the following phenotype:
CorrectAnswer: Homozygous loss of PMS2 leads to a high risk for developing colon cancer at very early ages, as well as brain tumors and other malignancies
Answer1: Heterozygote mutation carriers have a typical Lynch syndrome presentation, despite this being a rare genetic cause for Lynch syndrome
Answer2: Heterozygote mutation carriers are at high risk for developing colon cancer at very early ages, as well as brain tumors and other malignancies
Answer3: Homozygous loss of PMS2 is embryologically lethal

Question: Peutz Jeghers Syndrome is caused by mutations in which gene(s)?
CorrectAnswer: STK11
Answer2: MSH2/ MLH1

Question: Which of the following statements is true about Juvenile Polyposis?
CorrectAnswer: Juvenile polyps are most often hamartomatous
Answer1: The diagnosis requires at least 20 polyps in the colon
Answer2: The diagnosis requires at least 20 polyps in the small intestine
Answer3:
Juvenile polyps are by definition limited to those under age 
18
Answer4: The diagnosis requires at least 100 polyps in the colon or small intestine

Question: Looking at a pedigree from a family with known MYH polyposis, what pattern would you most likely observe?
CorrectAnswer: Multiple affected individuals limited to a single generation and sibship
Answer1: An affected male to female ratio of 3:1
Answer2: Vertical transmission with affected individuals in each generation
Answer3: Vertical transmission with affected individuals in most generations, with occasional skipping due to incomplete penetrance

Question: Which of the following statements is true about Turcot Syndrome?
CorrectAnswer: This condition can be caused by mutations in the genes for Lynch syndrome as well as the APC gene
Answer1: One can often observe characteristic freckling of the buccal mucosa starting in childhood, as well as brain tumors
Answer2: The condition gives rise to hamartomatous polyps but not typically until adulthood
Answer3:
The phenotype includes a high risk colon cancer and breast 
cancer

Question: Which of the following characteristics of a BRCA1 breast tumor make it distinctive from BRCA2 associated breast tumors?
CorrectAnswer: BRCA1 tumors are most often (but not exclusively) estrogen and progesterone receptor negative
Answer1: BRCA1 tumors are most often (but not exclusively) estrogen and progesterone receptor positive
Answer2: BRCA1 tumors more often are treated with hormonal therapy such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors
Answer3: BRCA1 tumors are more frequently invasive lobular carcinomas

Question: If you were providing genetic counseling to a family with a known founder mutation in BRCA1, 187delAG, what test would you order for other family members at risk?
CorrectAnswer: In an Ashkenazi Jewish family, one would order a test to look for the three common founder mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2
Answer1: In the setting of a known family mutation, one only needs to order site specific analysis for the known BRCA1 mutation
Answer2: In an Ashkenazi Jewish family, one would always order comprehensive analysis, or assessment of the entire sequence of both BRCA1 and BRCA2. since mutations are more common in this ethnic group
Answer3: In an Ashkenazi Jewish family, one would order a test to look for the other common founder mutations in BRCA1 in addition to 187delAG

Question: Which of the following is true about breast cancer genes and Fanconi Anemia (FA)?
CorrectAnswer: Compound heterozygotes of BRCA2 mutation will express the Fanconi Anemia phenotype
Answer1: There is no relationship between breast cancer genes and Fanconi Anemia
Answer2: Heterozygote mutation carriers for BRCA1 will occasionally express the phenotype for Fanconi Anemia
Answer3: Heterozygote mutation carriers for BRCA2 will occasionally express the phenotype of Fanconi Anemia

Question: Which is the most common cancer seen among women with Li-Fraumeni syndrome?
CorrectAnswer: Breast cancer
Answer2: Brain tumors

Question: Which syndrome is highly suggested by the finding of a trichilemomma?
CorrectAnswer: Cowden syndrome
Answer2: Von-Hippel Lindau

Question: Which of the following statements about Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) is TRUE?
CorrectAnswer: Individuals with this condition require upper endoscopic screening
Answer1: Basal cell carcinoma risk is much increased in individuals with FAP
Answer2: Once the colon has been completely removed, the risk for developing cancer is essentially eliminated
Answer3: Affected individuals will frequently develop hamartomatous polyps

Question: Which of the following are the three BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene mutations associated with Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry?
CorrectAnswer: 5385insC, 187delAG, 6174delT
Answer2: 187delAG, 834delT, 1100delC

Question: Individuals with a CDH1 gene mutation are more likely to have which of the    following type of breast cancer histology?
CorrectAnswer: Lobular
Answer2: Papillary

Question: What MMR gene mutations are overrepresented in the endometrial cancer population?
CorrectAnswer: MSH6
Answer2: MSH2

Question: What features are most predictive of an MMR mutation in a woman with endometrial cancer diagnosed under 50 years?   (BMI = body mass index)
CorrectAnswer: Positive family history and low BMI
Answer1: Positive family history and high BMI
Answer2: Negative family history and low BMI
Answer3: Negative family history and high BMI

Question: You meet with a 37-year old woman in the breast center regarding her family history of cancer.  She reports that her paternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 45.  She also reports that she has a personal history of a breast biopsy, which revealed atypical hyperplasia.  Which of the following models would give the MOST accurate estimation of her breast cancer risk?
CorrectAnswer: Tyrer-Cuzick
Answer2: Claus

Question: Which of the following pairs of breast cancer risk factors are closest in magnitude to each other?
CorrectAnswer: CHEK2 mutation and first degree relative with breast cancer
Answer2: BRCA2 mutation and first degree relative with breast cancer

Question: Which of the following tumor types are most clearly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1)?
CorrectAnswer: Hyperparathyroidism, gastrinomas, pituitary adenomas
Answer2: Pancreatic islet cell tumors, papillary thyroid cancer, hyperparathyriodism

Question: Your patient is a 49 year old recently diagnosed with colon cancer.  Her family history is significant for a sister with endometrial cancer at 45 years and a father with colon cancer at 63 years?  Immunohistochemical staining for MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 proteins in your patient’s tumor showed positive expression of the MLH1 and PMS2 protein products, but lack of expression of the MSH2 and MSH6 protein product.  Which of the following statements is FALSE?
CorrectAnswer: If genetic testing for MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 was completed and no mutation was found, this will rule out Lynch syndrome
Answer1: Based on this result it is likely that this tumor would also be MSI-H
Answer2: This family fulfills the revised Amsterdam criteria
Answer3: The most likely cause of the cancer in the family is due to an MSH2 mutation
Answer4: The risk for endometrial and ovarian cancer and the option of a hysterectomy/oophorectomy should be discussed with this patient

Question: What percent risk reduction is associated with a bilateral prophylactic mastectomy?
What percent (%) of VHL is due to a de novo mutation?
“Cobblestone gums” are suggestive of:
CorrectAnswer: Cowden syndrome
Answer2: Muir-Torre syndrome
Answer3: Gorlin syndrome/nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome

Question: Which extracolonic tumor is NOT part of the Bethesda guidelines for Lynch syndrome?
CorrectAnswer: Breast cancer
Answer2: Stomach cancer

Question: Which of the following statements about Hereditary Diffuse Gastric Cancer is CORRECT?
CorrectAnswer: CDH1 mutation testing only identifies mutations in 30-50% of families that meet criteria
Answer1: HDGC is associated with an increased risk for diffuse gastric cancer and ductal breast cancer
Answer2: There are many effective surveillance options that are available for early detection of diffuse gastric cancer
Answer3: Only a small proportion of individuals who undergo total gastrectomy are found to have foci of diffuse gastric on pathology

Question: A 32 year old woman presents to clinic given her personal history of melanoma diagnosed on her arm at the age of 28 and on her leg at the age of 30.  Her family history is significant for pancreatic cancer diagnosed in her mother at the age of 53, melanoma diagnosed in a maternal aunt in her 20s, and pancreatic cancer diagnosed in a maternal uncle in his 60s.  What gene would you consider offering testing for?
CorrectAnswer: CDKN2A (p16)
Answer2: SMAD4

Question: Which of the following patients is MOST likely to have an MMR mutation associated with Lynch syndrome?
CorrectAnswer: 45 y/o woman with synchronous endometrial and colon cancer
Answer1: 45 y/o woman with endometrial cancer and mother had ovarian cancer at age 67
Answer2: 45 y/o woman with endometrial cancer and mother had endometrial cancer at age 67
Answer3: 45 y/o woman with synchronous endometrial and ovarian cancer

Question: What percentage of RB1 mutations are de novo?
Medulloblastoma occurs at higher frequency in:
CorrectAnswer: Gorlin syndrome/nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome
Answer2: Muir-Torre syndrome

Question: What is the purpose of the Bethesda criteria?
CorrectAnswer: To identify a colorectal tumor that should be evaluated for MSI
Answer1: To diagnose a family with Lynch syndrome
Answer2: To identify a family suspicious for Lynch syndrome
Answer3: To  diagnose a colorectal tumor for MSI-H histology

Question: At what risk level is it appropriate for a woman to be offered chemoprevention in the form of tamoxifen or raloxifene to reduce her breast cancer risk?
CorrectAnswer: 1.7% 5 year risk as calculated by the Gail model
Answer1: 2.7% 5 year risk as calculated by the Claus model
Answer2: 1.7% 5 year risk as calculated by the Claus model
Answer3: 2.7% 5 year risk as calculated by the Gail model

Question: What is the earliest age at which 90% of patients with NF1 meet 2 or more of the NIH diagnostic criteria for NF1?
What pathological findings are more associated with a BRCA1 mutation?
CorrectAnswer: ER-, PR-, Her2 –
Answer2: ER +, PR -, Her2 +

Question: In the general population, which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the development of cancer?
CorrectAnswer: Age
Answer2: Hormonal factors

Question: Which of the following is most likely to be associated with Muir-Torre syndrome?
CorrectAnswer: Sebaceous adenoma in the head/neck area
Answer1: Sebaceous hyperplasia in the head/neck area
Answer2: Sebaceous adenoma on the trunk/limbs

Question: Pathology staining of a breast lesion is negative for E-cadherin.  What type of breast lesion is this?
CorrectAnswer: Lobular
Answer2: Papillary

Question: Legius syndrome, caused by mutations of the SPRED1 gene, is associated with:
CorrectAnswer: Café au lait macules and axillary/inguinal freckling
Answer2: Café au lait macules and optic glioma

Question: Which gene has the HIGHEST ovarian cancer risk?
CorrectAnswer: BRCA1
Answer2: MMR genes

Question: Schwannomas are a characteristic finding in individuals with germline mutations in which genes?
CorrectAnswer: NF2 and SMARCB1
Answer2: NF1 and SMARCB1

Question: Which of the following tumor types are most clearly associated with Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL)?
CorrectAnswer: Pheochromocytoma, endolymphatic sac tumors, hemangioblastoma
Answer1: Clear cell renal carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, glioblastomas
Answer2: Clear cell renal carcinoma, osteosarcoma, pancreatic adenocarcinoma
Answer3: Pancreatic islet cell tumors, hemangioblastoma, osteosarcoma

Question: Which of the following is NOT a hereditary risk factor for developing melanoma?
CorrectAnswer: A previous history of a non melanoma skin cancer
Answer2: Skin that always burns

Question: A 4 year old boy presents to clinic with several hyperpigmented lesions of the skin. Upon further evaluation an ophthalmologist detects Lisch nodules.  You also are made aware that the patient’s mother has these same skin findings and has in the past had trouble learning in school.  What condition does the patient most likely have?
CorrectAnswer: Neurofibromatosis 1
Answer2: Xeroderma Pigmentosum

Question: Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with hamartomatous gastrointestinal polyps?
CorrectAnswer: MYH-associated polyposis
Answer2: Cowden syndrome
